intro: Apinagia kochii, commonly known as the Koch's apinagia, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and related shrubs. The plant is characterized by its evergreen leaves and clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that bloom in late spring. It thrives in well-drained, acidic soils and requires a cool, humid climate. Apinagia kochii is often found in alpine meadows and rocky habitats at high elevations.
